Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was bom in Portland, Milne, to distinguished and
wel!-4ducated parents. The elder Longfellow was a prosperous lawyer and gave
his sone an excellent education, both in the United States and in Europe.
Extensive traveling allowed Longfellow not only to broaden his experience, but
to perfect his knowledge of languages and to meet well-known figures in the art
world.
Longfellow married in 1831. For several years he taught modem languages
and literature at Bowdoin College. IXurlng this period, he wrote many of his
best known poems—“The Wreck of the Hesperus”, "The Village Blacksmith." and
"A Psalm of Idfe."
After the tragic death of his wife, Longfellow continued to teach and to
write. The "Song of Hiawatha" and "Evangeline" were ^published duxfcng this
period. He was particularly attracted to the contemporary Gorman literature
of the gats period in which he lived.
In 1843, he married again, but his second wife too died suddenly. The
personal tragedies of Longfellow’s life most certainly influenced his works the
nature poems of his youth contrast markedly with the more philosophical poetry
of his later years.
Longfellow was the first American poet to receive recognition in Europe,
and although his reputation among critics has since declined, his verses are
still quoted by millions of people.
